history.content:
170 and 188 won't help for the programming: 170 hardly has any programming, and 188 programming is relatively easy. Programming experience you get through the 61 series should be plenty. 170 does give you more proof experience which can be helpful.

126 tends to be pretty useful, because probability is important and after taking 70 you still don't understand enough in my experience. Although 126 is considered very difficult, so Stat 134 as suggested is a great alternative.

127 is far from necessary, if you do want to take it you can just take it concurrently instead of before. The biggest thing you get from 127 is more linear algebra experience, but you can largely self-study that (16AB is not sufficient imo, I needed to relearn SVD and the spectral theorem and also learn some new stuff like PSD matrices).

However after saying all this, I still recommend you take a lot of these classes. 170 is useful in general, 188 gives you a lot of knowledge about AI that goes beyond just ML, and 126 and 127 can be cool classes in their own right.

children.subject: Thank you! Would you say something like 61c, 170, 127 + a breadth would be a manageable schedule? Based on the two answers I'm leaning to 127 since I'd say I was doing alright in the probability parts of 70 and will rely on that since it is listed as an alternate for the probability requirement
Or would you agree with the other answer in that 70 is not enough?
<md>61c is pretty heavy. 170, 127, and a breadth is doable. Unless you're comfortably taking 3 techs every sem, that schedule would not be doable.</md>
Sorry, I'm a freshman so I'm not really sure. How many techs/non-techs are recommended to take per semester? Do people usually take 3 or 4 total classes per semester?

The number of classes you take should be determined by where you feel comfortable rather than what most people do. I'd say its most common to take two, but many people take three (and less often four) techs at once. The other classes are usually breadths/for another major/just for fun. If you are EECS I believe you must take 2 techs each semester and CS has more flexibility. I will say that you can comfortably graduate taking 2 techs most semesters.
ive done 61c/127/170/breadth and it was tough conceptually but pretty manageable in terms of workload, you can definitely do that

<md>The student's response is a bit misleading. I've done 126, 127, and 170, and currently taking 189 with Shewchuk. The "enough programming experience" is easily satisfied by 61b. I'm assuming you've already taken this. EECS 127 helps quite a lot, unlike the student response suggests. It gives a lot of useful insight into how SVMs work, convex optimization in general, as well as applications for a lot of useful facts in linear algebra (like spectral theorem, SVD, etc.). It also gets you really familiar with matrix calculus, which is used a lot in 189. In fact, I've found it to be more useful than 126 so far. 126 is still useful though. The probability intuition is really helpful for things like bias-variance decomposition, etc. I would recommend taking 126 instead of stat 134. I have not taken the latter but I am sort of familiar with the material since a close friend of mine took the course (and I helped him with some of the assignments). That class does not teach stuff like MLE/MAP, information theory, etc. It's this kind of applied knowledge that helps a ton in 189. If you can, then take 126</md>

Yet another opinion: 127 does not feel that necessary for Prof Shewchuk 189. Both are problem set heavy, especially at the beginning of the semester. If you are comfortable with linear algebra, it may be better to spend time focusing on 189 and getting a better understanding of those concepts.

history.content:
I will be taking CS61C to finish off the lower divs in the fall. Alongside I was thinking something like this: 61C, 170, one of 126 or 127 or 188 and a breadth. I want to take 189 as soon as I can so I was thinking I'd be ready in the Fall with a schedule like that? I haven't done multivariable calc but I intend to self-study the relevant parts over winter break and a bit this summer. How would the courseload be and which of the 3 would be best to prepare for 189? Looking at the list on Prof. Shewchuck's site, I have 16A+B and 70 and will self study 53. I suppose 170 and 188 would help for programming experience but 126 is also listed. Lastly, I've heard others say 127 helped a lot too.
  • Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),
  • Math 54, Math 110, or EE 16A+16B (or another linear algebra course),
  • CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
  • Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)
history.subject: sophomore courseload
